An **ice troll**, T, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a type of [troll](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") that is slower than a normal troll, but has stronger attacks and better defenses. Like all trolls, ice trolls can often [revive](/wiki/Revive "Revive") from its corpse when killed.

An ice troll has a weapon attack, a claw attack that inflicts cold damage, and a bite attack - the claw attack can freeze and shatter [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") in the target's open inventory. Naturally, it also possesses [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance").

Eating an ice troll [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 3⁄5 chance of conveying cold resistance.

[ ]

## Contents

## Generation

Randomly generated ice trolls are always generated hostile.

Ice trolls may appear among the hostile T that generate in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), as well the monsters randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Ice trolls can generate among the random T that are part of the second quest [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters that randomly generate on the [Barbarian quest](/wiki/Barbarian_quest "Barbarian quest").

Ice trolls have a 1⁄2 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [ranseur](/wiki/Ranseur "Ranseur"), [partisan](/wiki/Partisan "Partisan"), [glaive](/wiki/Glaive "Glaive"), or [spetum](/wiki/Spetum "Spetum"), with an equal probability of each polearm.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

Ice trolls are slower than basic trolls, but have stronger attacks and can destroy any potions you are carrying in the open with their claw attack. They also have an [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 20, making magical attacks somewhat less reliable against ice trolls (though still effective).

The same strategies for disposing of troll corpses apply to ice troll corpses: you can [eat](/wiki/Eat "Eat") them (as can a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet")), [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") them, lock them in a [box](/wiki/Box "Box"), throw them into [water](/wiki/Pool "Pool") or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"), turn them to [stone](/wiki/Stone "Stone"), or even lure them to the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level"), where monsters do not drop corpses. Eating an ice troll may be more attractive than other options for a character without [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), as their corpses have a 60% chance of granting it - if you plan to eat one for this purpose, try to keep meat-eating pets away from the corpse.

## History

The ice troll first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Troll](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troll "wikipedia:Troll")***

A troll is a being that appears in Norse mythology and later Scandinavian folklore. In Old Norse sources, beings described as trolls dwell in isolated areas of rock, mountains, or caves, living together in small family units, and were rarely helpful to human beings - the Old Norse nouns *troll* and *trǫll* are variously used to mean "fiend", "demon", "werewolf", and "jötunn". The trolls of *NetHack* are derived from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, whose portrayal of them is partly inspired by [Poul Anderson](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poul_Anderson "wikipedia:Poul Anderson") novel *[Three Hearts and Three Lions](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Hearts_and_Three_Lions "wikipedia:Three Hearts and Three Lions")*.

*D\&D* trolls are typically nine feet tall on average, with rubbery green or gray hide, gaunt and deceptively-thin builds, and long arms that drag across the ground and dangle when running. A troll's hunched posture and uneven gait masks great physical strength and agility: they are fearless fighters that attack relentlessly with their claws and teeth, rarely using weapons, and have the ability to rapidly heal wounds and even animate disembodied parts of themselves, as well as a weakness to fire. Trolls hunt most other living creatures for prey and have no natural predators, though they respect groups that are known to wield fire - both fire and acid were the only ways of counteracting a troll's regenerative abilities.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), ice trolls [hit as a +1 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon"), and tame ice trolls may turn [traitor](/wiki/Traitor "Traitor").

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), ice trolls may appear as [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") in the Ice Caves adventure branch.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), four ice trolls are generated on the last floor of the [Ice Queen's Realm](/wiki/Ice_Queen%27s_Realm "Ice Queen's Realm") at level creation: two are stationed in the watchtowers of the Ice Queen's castle, and the other two are placed in front of the doors that connect the [zoo](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo") to the foyer leading into the Ice Queen's dwelling.

## Encyclopedia entry

The troll shambled closer. He was perhaps eight feet tall,  
perhaps more. His forward stoop, with arms dangling past  
thick claw-footed legs to the ground, made it hard to tell.  
The hairless green skin moved upon his body. His head was a  
gash of a mouth, a yard-long nose, and two eyes which drank  
the feeble torchlight and never gave back a gleam.  
\[...]  
Like a huge green spider, the troll's severed hand ran on its  
fingers. Across the mounded floor, up onto a log with one  
taloned forefinger to hook it over the bark, down again it  
 scrambled, until it found the cut wrist. And there it grew  
fast. The troll's smashed head seethed and knit together.  
He clambered back on his feet and grinned at them. The  
waning faggot cast red light over his fangs.

\[ Three Hearts and Three Lions, by Poul Anderson ]
